content:
• Thursday, October 17, 2013

  • After-hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: ALGN +14%. ALIM +9%. CPHD +5%. CMG +5%. HCA +4%.
    • Top losers, as of 5:15 p.m.: ACTG -13%. VLCCF -13%. AMD -8%. ISRG -6%. TSO -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:42 PM | 6 Comments
  • CY

    Cypress pares post-earnings losses following CC

    • Down over 8% at one point today after posting its Q3 results (slightly better than the numbers provided in its Sep. 24 warning), Cypress (CY -1.5%) rallied after providing a somewhat encouraging CC.
    • The chipmaker guided on the CC for Q4 revenue of $163M-$170M and EPS of $0.07-$0.09 vs. a consensus of $167.3M and $0.07. Though admitting mobile weakness will pressure Q4 results (as disclosed in the warning), Cypress also suggested the weakness was due in large part to the push-out of two major OEM programs to Q1 2014. Shipments related to one of the programs will begin at the end of Q4.
    • Cypress also disclosed it took a look at mobile fingerprint sensor developer Validity Sensors prior to its acquisition by Synaptics, but decided to pass.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:36 PM
  • DZSI

    Zhone rockets after reporting Q3 earnings

    • Zhone (ZHNE): Q3 EPS of $0.05 vs. -$0.14 in 3Q12.
    • Revenue of $31.5M vs. 29.2M in 3Q12. Shares +21.4% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:32 PM
  • CPE

    Callon Petroleum sells Gulf of Mexico assets to W&T Offshore

    • Callon Petroleum (NYSE:CPE) agrees to sell its interests in the Medusa field and Medusa Spar and substantially all of its Gulf of Mexico shelf assets to W&TÂ Offshore (NYSE:WTI) for $100M, as CPE completes the shift of its focus to the Permian Basin.
    • Based on current drilling plans, CPE expects to end 2013 producing 3,500 boe from its Permian Basin position, with a solid balance sheet to pursue acquisitions and further accelerate drilling activity.
    • CPE +2.6% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:51 PM
  • AMD

    AMD -7.6% AH; guidance above consensus, margins expected to drop again

    • AMD is guiding for Q4 revenue to be up 5% Q/Q (+/- 3%); the midpoint is above a consensus for 3.4% growth. But gross margin is expected to fall another 100 bps Q/Q to 35%, after dropping 300 bps in Q3 to 36% (in-line with guidance, but aided by a 100 bps boost from an inventory sale). In July, margin concerns led AMD to sell off following its Q2 report.
    • CPU division sales -6% Q/Q and -15% Y/Y to $790M, thanks to PC industry weakness and share loss. The division had op. income of $22M. Intel's PC CPU division sales rose 4% Q/Q and fell 3% Y/Y in Q3.
    • Graphics & Visual Solutions (inc. GPUs and consoles) sales soared 110% Q/Q and 96% Y/Y thanks to the console ramps. Division op. income totaled $79M.
    • CPU ASP was flat Q/Q and down Y/Y. GPU ASP was down Q/Q and Y/Y. Semi-custom and embedded sales (inc. consoles) made up 30% of revenue.
    • Thanks to job cuts, R&D spend -12% Y/Y to $288M. MG&A -18% to $155M.
    • AMD was free cash flow positive in Q3, and expects to be so again in Q4. Cash/investments stood at $1.2B at the end of Q3, and debt at $2.05B.
    • CC at 5:30PM ET. Q3 results, PR, CFO comments, slides
     
     
     
     
    | 4:50 PM | 7 Comments
  • ISRG

    Intuitive Surgical systems revenue falls 32% in Q3

    • Intuitive Surgical (NASDAQ:ISRG) sinks 7% AH as Q3 revenue comes up well short of consensus.
    • da Vinci surgical procedures +16% Y/Y.
    • Systems revenue tumbles 32% from Q2 2012 as sales of da Vinci robots fall 35% Y/Y. "System sales were down in Q3 primarily as a result of moderating growth in benign gynecology, combined with changing hospital capital spending priorities associated with the implementation of the ACA," the company says.
    • Operating income -17.5% Y/Y. Net income -14.2%.
    • "Our third quarter results were impacted by the same pressures we faced in the first half of the year," CEO Gary Guthart notes. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:38 PM
  • WDFC

    WD-40 beats by $0.05, beats on revenues

    • WD-40 (NASDAQ:WDFC): FQ4 EPS of $0.53 beats by $0.05.
    • Revenue of $93.5M (+10% Y/Y) beats by $3.45M. Shares +3.2% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:34 PM
  • CMLP

    Crestwood Midstream to offer 14M common units, -4.9% AH

    • Crestwood Midstream Partners (NYSE:CMLP) -4.9%Â AH after announcing a public offering of 14M common units.
    • CMLP plans to use net proceeds to fund part of its pending acquisition of Arrow Midstream Holdings and related transaction costs and expenses.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:29 PM
  • OMER

    Omeros files S-3, shares slide

    • Omeros (NASDAQ:OMER) files a $100M mixed shelf. (S-3)
    • OMER -2% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:27 PM | 1 Comment
  • ATHN

    athenahealth misses, affirms guidance

    • athenahealth (NASDAQ:ATHN) reverses course to trade essentially flat AH. The stock initially tumbled 6.6% after the company missed on both lines with its Q3 report.
    • Core revenues rose 27% during the period, gross margin fell 80 bps, and operating margin fell 560 bps from the year ago period.
    • The company added a record number of doctors to its cloud services during the quarter and CFO Tim Adams says ATHN remains "on track to post another strong year of financial and operational performance."
    • Full year guidance is reaffirmed: Adjusted EPSÂ of $1.05-1.15 on revenue of $580-615M. Consensus is $1.02/share on $594.7M in sales. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:24 PM
  • EVEP-OLD

    EV Energy to offer 5M common units, -4.6% AH

    • EVÂ Energy Partners (NASDAQ:EVEP-OLD) -4.6% AH after announcing a public offering of 5M common units.
    • EVEP says it plans to use net proceeds to pay down debt.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:24 PM
  • CPHD

    Cepheid rockets on higher earnings

    • Cepheid (NASDAQ:CPHD): Q3 EPS of $0.09 beats by $0.10.
    • Revenue of $100.1M (+24% Y/Y) beats by $6.4M. Shares +3.9% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM
  • RMBS

    Rambus beats by $0.04, beats on revenue

    • Rambus (NASDAQ:RMBS): Q3 EPS of $0.15 beats by $0.04.
    • Revenue of $73.3M beats by $2.8M. Shares +2.40% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:15 PM
  • CMG

    Sales up, margins down at Chipotle during Q3

    • Chipotle (NYSE:CMG) reports comparable store sales rose 6.2% during Q3 on an increase in store traffic.
    • Restaurant level operating margin slipped 60 bps to 26.8% as higher food costs and marketing expenses factored in.
    • The company expects comparable restaurant sales growth in the mid single-digit for 2013 and low single-digits for 2014 (unless menu prices are increased).
    • CMG +2.6% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:11 PM | 3 Comments
  • ISRG

    Intuitive Surgical slides on Q3 earnings

    • Intuitive Surgical (NASDAQ:ISRG): Q3 EPS of $3.99 beats by $0.62.
    • Revenue of $499M (-7% Y/Y) misses by $26.47M. Shares -4.8% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:07 PM
  • ATHN

    AthenaHealth misses by $0.02, misses on revenue

    • AthenaHealth (NASDAQ:ATHN): Q3 EPS of $0.29 misses by $0.02.
    • Revenue of $151.5M (+43% Y/Y) misses by $3.3M. Shares -5.18% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:04 PM
  • PTIE

    Pain Therapeutics, Durect rise sharply

    • Shares of Pain Therapeutics (NASDAQ:PTIE) and Durect (NASDAQ:DRRX) finish the day higher by 16% and 9% respectively.
    • When these two move together investors may be expecting some news out of Pfizer (NYSE:PFE) regarding Remoxy.
    • PFE Q3 call is October 29
     
     
     
     
    | 4:04 PM | 7 Comments
  • GOOG

    Google beats by $0.37, beats on revenues

    • Google (NASDAQ:GOOG): Q3 EPS of $10.74 beats by $0.37.
    • Revenue of $14.89B beats by $0.05B. Shares +1.9% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:03 PM | 19 Comments
  • UNH

    Wells Fargo cuts numbers but maintains Buy rating on UnitedHealth

    • On the Q3 call, UnitedHealth (UNH -5.2%) said it will continue to face headwinds from Medicare Advantage and non-deductible premium tax, Wells Fargo's Peter Costa notes, adding that the company "will likely provide a wide initial range of guidance for FY14 that straddles both the low and high end of it FY13 guidance range."
    • Despite today's lackluster session, Costa maintains an Outperform rating on the shares.
    • FY14 and FY15 EPSÂ estimates are cut to $5.80 (from $6) and $6.85 (from $7.05).
    • Price target reduced to $81-87 from $84-90.
    • More on UNH's quarter here and here
     
     
     
     
    | 3:37 PM
  • ACRX

    Cowen sees opportunity in AcelRx amid weakness

    • Cowen is apparently out reiterating a Buy on AcelRx (ACRX +4.1%).
    • Coming into today, the shares were off some 22% since the Zalviso NDA filing.
    • According to market chatter, Edward Nash thinks the sell-off has created a compelling buying opportunity.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:24 PM | 1 Comment
  • NEM

    Gold prices, miners surge on debt deal, QE hopes

    • Gold futures (GLD +3.2%) settle more than $40/oz. higher, boosted by the belief that the debt default deal might prompt the Fed to delay reducing QE.
    • "The U.S. debt deal is seen (as) positive for gold by market participants, for good reason, since the whole mess is just being postponed by 3-4 months, which makes a reduction of Fed asset purchases rather unlikely for the time being," Commerzbank says.
    • Many probably believed gold would fall if there was no debt default, so a short squeeze likely is helping force prices higher.
    • Among the day's biggest equity gainers are gold miners (GDX +6.2%): NEM +4.8%, ABX +5.4%, GG +4.2%, GFI +3.9%, RGLD +7.1%, KGC +4.9%, NGD +5.3%.
    • ETFs: IAU, SGOL, PHYS, AGOL, DGL, UBG, DGP, UGL, DZZ, GLL, DGZ, UGLD, DGLD, GLDI, GDXJ, GLDX, PSAU, NUGT, DUST, GGGG, RING.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:21 PM | 11 Comments
  • TRIT

    Tri-Tech soars on China water decree

    • Shares of Tri-Tech Holding (TRIT +32.1%) spike suddenly on heavy volume.
    • Some suggest the move is attributable to Chinese Premier Li Keqiang's signing of a new decree which mandates that governments above the county level integrate urban drainage and sewage treatment facilities in their economic planning efforts.
    • In order to address a "grave" water pollution situation, the government is raisingÂ  the amount allocated to water pollution control in major drainage areas to Â¥500B over five years from Â¥300B over the previous five-year period.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:51 PM
  • LNVGY

    Lenovo reportedly signs NDA with BlackBerry

    • Dow Jones reports Lenovo (OTCPK:LNVGY) has signed an NDA to look at BlackBerry's (BBRY +1.6%) books. The report comes two days after one from Bloomberg indicating an NDA has been signed with Cerberus.
    • Lenovo has been featured in BlackBerry M&A speculation more than once this year, in part due to comments from Lenovo execs. But the Chinese PC/smartphone vendor's relatively small market cap could be an issue, as might national security concerns (should Lenovo want to acquire BlackBerry's network).
    • BlackBerry has rallied a bit on the report.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:48 PM | 36 Comments
  • BTU

    Peabody earnings call: Cost controls outweigh falling coal prices

    • Among key points from Peabody Energy's (BTU +3.1%) Q3 conference call, coal demand from China is expected at ~200M tons/year for the next five years, and it has seen improving macroeconomic conditions that support continued coal demand growth from China and more developed economies.
    • In the U.S., Q3 volumes of nearly 50M tons reflect seasonal increases, particularly in the Powder River Basin; BTU does not see erosion in the Powder River Basin when looking at natural gas futures.
    • In Australia, volumes rose 6% to 9M tons on increased output from several mines.
    • Capex totaled $62M, 80% below prior-year levels, and capital targets for the full year are further reduced to $350M-$400M as the company continues to manage spending for the rest of the year. (Q3 earnings)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:42 PM
  • IBM

    IBM makes new 52-week lows post-earnings; are more acquisitions on tap?

    • UBS' Steve Milunovich, who downgraded IBM (IBM -6.8%) to Hold following its $1.07B Q3 revenue miss: "Results could improve as 2014 unfolds, but the next two quarters likely won’t be too encouraging ... Normally we would wait out mediocre results ... but there are too many questions this time." He observes IBM was only able to maintain full-year EPS guidance because of the $0.40/share Q3 boost provided by a lower tax rate.
    • SocGen (Hold) thinks IBM might once more turn to M&A to lift growth. In particular, the firm considers major app software purchases a possibility as database and middleware sales are pressured by the cloud transition. IBM's middleware sales rose 1% Y/Y in Q3, and "information management" sales (inc. databases) rose 2%. OS sales, hurt by server weakness, fell 4%.
    • CLSA is staying bullish, praising IBM's efforts to deal with industry pressures by making large analytics/cloud investments. Wells Fargo (Market Perform) expects a new buyback to be announced on Oct. 29, but also thinks "visibility to the 2015 $20 EPS target has become murkier."
    • More on IBM's Q3: I, II. CC transcript.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:08 PM | 2 Comments
  • ARIA

    Most doctors surveyed plan no change to Iclusig prescriptions: JPMorgan

    • Strength in shares of Ariad Pharmaceuticals (ARIA +8.9%) has held up well throughout the session.
    • From the JPMorgan note which sparked the rally: "The majority of docs we surveyed who have used Iclusig do not expect their use to change over the next 6-12 months [and] somewhat surprisingly, there were more docs who expect to increase their use of the drug vs. docs who expect use to decrease."
    • As noted earlier, this would seem to suggest that investor concern over a recent FDA drug safety communication (see here and here)Â may be overblown.
    • As for comparisons between Iclusig and Novartis' (NVS +1.4%)Â Tasigna, JPM says "only 4% of docs view Iclusig’s safety profile as 'significantly worse' than Tasigna" (52% of Iclusig-prescribing docs characterize the drug's safety profile is "moderately worse").
     
     
     
     
    | 2:06 PM
  • ZIOP

    Ziopharm surges, extends recent gains

    • Shares of Ziopharm Oncology (ZIOP +9.9%) are trading sharply higher on the session.
    • Earlier, the company announced that it, along with Intrexon (XON +0.1%), will present at the International Conference on Molecular Targets and Cancer Therapeutics this month.
    • The poster presentations will highlight ZIOP's "monogenic system which enables the controlled delivery of therapeutic interleukin-12, in a brain tumor model," as well as other pipeline programs. (PR)
    • With today's gains, the shares are up ~52% since September 27, when the company presented at the Biotech Industry Conference in New York.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:42 PM
  • XSPA

    Vringo gets a lift from ParkerVision/Qualcomm verdict

    • Vringo (VRNG +2.2%) spiked higher following news a Florida jury ruled Qualcomm is infringing ParkerVision's RF chip IP (ParkerVision shares have soared on the news). Shares have since pared their gains, but remain above where they traded before the announcement was made.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:34 PM | 1 Comment
  • UNH

    UnitedHealth fails to impress, weakness drags on peers

    • Investors aren't satisfied with UnitedHealth's (UNH -4.9%) quarter, as the stock is notably lower on heavy volume.
    • Although the company matched Street estimates, profit ticked up only slightly Y/Y and the company's FY EPSÂ guidance of $5.40-5.50 is still below consensus estimates.
    • Also lower on the day: WLP -1.4%, HUM -3.4%, AET -1.9%
    • Earnings
     
     
     
     
    | 1:28 PM | 1 Comment
  • NUS

    Citron does its thing on Nu Skin and algorithms do theirs

    • Nu Skin (NUS -2%) drops almost instantaneously after Citron Research issues a negative report on the company.
    • The interesting part isn't so much what Citron has to say about Nu Skin, but the role that trading algorithms might be playing in monitoring the firm's Twitter handle and website for new takedown pieces.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:19 PM | 1 Comment
  • PRKR

    ParkerVision rockets after resumption, trips circuit-breaker

    • ParkerVision (OTC:PRKR +72%) shares rocket up after a halt is lifted only to trip the circuit-breaker and be halted again.
    • Previous:Â Jury finds for ParkerVision in Qualcomm patent infringement lawsuit
     
     
     
     
    | 1:03 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Top 10 Gainers: CNR +97%. RSOL +33%. KGJI +17%. NTCT +16%. UFPI +14%. SCON +13%. VIMC +13%. ASTM +13%. DRRX +13%. CSUN +12%.
    • Top 10 Losers: AMRN -61%. SCSS -22%. BORN -16%. OSTK -14%. VISN -13%. OTC:ANW -13%. PSDV -12%. SAEX -12%. TZOO -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:57 PM
  • CCJ

    Cameco slide reflects seasonality, BMO says

    • The price of uranium has stabilized in the last month, but shares of Cameco (CCJ +2.1%) have been in steady decline; BMO says there's nothing unusual about the downward move, and it seems to happen every year around this time.
    • The early fall is a seasonally weak period for uranium, but the seasonality may also have to do with CCJ's sales schedule, which tends to be heavily back-loaded to the fourth quarter, BMO says, so investors need not get too edgy about whether the company can finish the year strong enough to meet its annual guidance.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:29 PM
  • CLB

    Core Labs surges after strong Q3 report, Cramer endorses

    • Core Labs (CLB +7.1%) shares are surging after beating Q3 estimates, the fourth straight quarter in which CLB has posted records for EPS, net income and revenue.
    • CLB expects Q4 EPS of $1.39-$1.40, in line with analyst consensus estimates, and revenues of $278M-$281M vs. consensus $275M.
    • As CLBÂ CEOÂ David Demshur offered an optimistic outlook, Jim Cramer gave his seal of approval to the stock, claiming CLB was one of the strongest companies to merge science with business.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:16 PM
  • AMBA

    Ambarella makes new highs following Chardan coverage launch

    • Chardan's Jay Srivasta is only giving Ambarella (AMBA +4.7%) a Neutral rating and $20 PT due to a valuation of 20x estimated FY14 (ends Jan. '14) EPS. But he praises the video-processing SoC developer's positioning within the wearable sports camera, automotive aftermarket camera, and security camera markets.
    • Ambarella is making fresh post-IPO highs. Shares took off last month after the chipmaker beat FQ2 estimates on the back of surging security market demand, and issued solid FQ3 guidance.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:15 PM
  • ATLS

    Atlas Energy, Atlas Resource fall after Baird downgrades

    • Atlas Energy (OTC:ATLS -7.5%) and Atlas Resource Partners (ARP -2.6%) are downgraded to Neutral from Outperform with respective target prices of $50 and $22 at Robert W. Baird, citing a substantially reduced return profile and a worsened outlook.
    • ARP followed in the "ignominious steps" of its sister midstream partnership Atlas Pipeline Partners (APL +0.1%) with an H2 profit warning, the firm says, precipitating the downgrades. (earlier)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:43 AM | 5 Comments
  • MBI

    Puerto Rico reiterates intention to pay bills

    • The bond insurers are having a reasonable day after Puerto Rico Governor Padilla denied the territory is near bankruptcy or needs a bailout. "We will do everything, and I repeat, everything that is necessary for Puerto Rico to honor all its commitments ... It's not only a constitutional but also a moral obligation."
    • What else would you expect him to say? Plenty. Part of the bull case on those exposed to Puerto Rico is the stark difference in attitudes about bill-paying between the PR government and that of Detroit.
    • Also maybe helping is another report from MKM's Harry Fong, arguing Puerto Rico will not default and all general obligation bonds will be paid.
    • MBIA (MBI +2%), Assured Guaranty (AGO +1.5%), Ambac (AMBC -0.7%).
     
     
     
     
    | 11:10 AM | 3 Comments
  • RIC

    Commercial production begins at Richmont's W Zone gold project

    • Richmont Mines (RIC +4.1%) says its W Zone gold project in Quebec has successfully completed the three month pre-production phase and commercial production has been declared.
    • RIC expects W Zone to produce ~3K oz. of commercial gold production during Q4 and projects 12K oz. of commercial gold production in 2014.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:55 AM
  • OLED

    TheStreetSweeper shorts Universal Display, shares slump

    • TheStreetSweeper on Twitter: "TheStreetSweeper announces new short position in $OLED and imminent release of its next report on a brand-new company today."
    • Universal Display (OLED -3.3%) has fallen in response to the disclosure. TheStreetSweeper took aim at the company back in 2011, criticizing insider selling and the terms of the Samsung deal (among other things).
     
     
     
     
    | 10:52 AM | 17 Comments
  • BIDU

    Baidu rises, Citi hikes mobile revenue forecasts

    • Citi, which had a Sell rating on Baidu (BIDU +1.1%) as late as mid-July, has now become one of the Chinese search giant's biggest fans. The firm has raised its PT to $175, and now expects mobile to respectively account for 21% and 28% of Baidu's 2014 and 2015 revenue, up from a prior 18% and 22%.
    • Citi expects mobile sales to be lifted by higher mobile search volumes, growing ad inventory, and Baidu's popular non-search mobile services. It also sees mobile revenue carrying higher incremental margins than PC revenue due to lower traffic acquisition costs (TAC).
    • The latter argument might raise some eyebrows, given non-Chinese search firms, including Google and Yahoo, are seeing higher TACs on mobile due to revenue-sharing deals with OEMs and carriers.
    • Previous: Citi talks up Baidu's mobile search growth
     
     
     
     
    | 10:29 AM
  • ARIA

    Ariad rises after JPMorgan defends shares

    • Beleaguered Ariad Pharmaceuticals (ARIA +10.4%) is enjoying a strong session thus far.
    • Market chatter (here, here, and here) indicates that the move is likely attributable to a JPMorgan note in which analysts say physicians may be less concerned about Iclusig's safety profile than investors.
    • JPM price target reportedly is $12.
    • More on the Iclusig issue here
     
     
     
     
    | 10:19 AM
  • KERX

    Keryx Biopharmaceuticals extends gains

    • Shares of Keryx Biopharmaceuticals (KERX +9.4%) are up sharply again today, after surging nearly 20% Wednesday.
    • The two-day rally now totals some 30%.
    • Behind the move: A pair of upbeat analyst notes and generalized optimism for Zerenex.
    • For more, see SA contributor PropThink's latest piece on why the drug is "more than just a dialysis product."
    • Also: Zerenex abstracts have been selected for oral and poster presentations at ASN early next month. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:04 AM | 1 Comment
  • GS

    Goldman reviews tough quarter on earnings call

    • "Franchise feels good, we just had a tough quarter," says Goldman Sachs (GS -2.4%) CFO Harvey Schwartz on the company earnings call (still in Q&A, listen live here). Everyone knew trading revenue was set to take a hit at the big banks this quarter, but Goldman's 44% decline was especially bad (Citi fell 26%, BofA 20%, JPM 8%). Why?
    • Schwartz suggests it's the mix of clients: Goldman has more asset managers who pulled back from trading amid the volatility, while the others cater more to hedge funds who are less likely to shy away from action. "I don't want to sound defensive ... not a good quarter for us."
    • Earlier: Q3 results.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:01 AM | 1 Comment
  • FSM

    Fortuna Mines increases San Jose silver reserves by 22%

    • Fortuna Silver Mines (FSM +8.7%) updates its mineral reserve and resource estimates for its San Jose Mine in Mexico.
    • Proven and probable reserves total 3.9 metric tons containing 24.8M oz. silver and 215K oz. gold, reflecting respective increases of 22% and 27% from Dec. 31, 2012 estimates.
    • Inferred resources total 5.4 metric tons containing 35.3M oz. silver and 272K oz. gold, reflecting respective increases of 39% and 27% from Dec. 31, 2012 estimates.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:59 AM
  • GMCR

    Green Mountain Coffee Roasters turns lower

    • Shares of Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR -4.8%) retreat after Doughtery downgrades the company to Neutral.
    • Over the last month GMCR is down over 25%, influenced in part by some K-Cup growth trends.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:57 AM
  • IBM

    A roundup of tech ratings changes

    • IBM (IBM -5.9%) has been cut to Neutral by UBS following its big Q3 revenue miss.
    • Xilinx (XLNX -5%) has been downgraded to neutral ratings by Piper and Raymond James, and upgraded to Outperform by Baird, and after beating FQ3 estimates and issuing soft FQ4 revenue guidance.
    • SanDisk (SNDK +5.8%) has been upgraded to Strong Buy by Needham after soundly beating Q3 estimates and issuing decent Q4 revenue guidance.
    • JinkoSolar (JKS +10.3%) has been has been upgraded to Outperform by Credit Suisse.
    • ASML (ASML -1.9%) has been cut to Neutral by HSBC a day after releasing its Q3 results.
    • CEVA (CEVA -1.3%) has been cut to Neutral by Wedbush.
    • Salesforce (CRM +0.3%) has been started at Buy by Argus.
    • SolarCity (SCTY +8.9%) has been started at Overweight by JPMorgan a week after providing strong Q3 metrics and even stronger 2014 guidance.
    • NQ Mobile (NQ +6%) and Vipshop (VIPS -0.7%) havebeen started at Outperform by Macquarie.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:56 AM
  • ALKS

    Citi hikes target on Alkermes

    • Citi is out reiterating a Buy on Alkermes (ALKS +2.6%).
    • Analyst Jonathan Eckard raises his price target to $43 (from $38) representing a 32% upside from Wednesday's close.
    • Eckard cites "increased estimates for late-stage programs, introduction of estimates for earlier stage programs, and a lower outyear tax rate."
    • Pipeline is here
     
     
     
     
    | 9:47 AM | 2 Comments
  • VZ

    Verizon's Q3 subscriber adds impress, shares rise

    • Verizon (VZ +2.4%) added 1.1M net retail wireless connections in Q3, and saw 927K retail postpaid net adds. Those figures compare with 1M and 941K in Q2, and are evidence Big Red continues to take U.S. mobile share. Total retail postpaid connections +5% Y/Y to 95.2M, total retail connections +5% to 101.2M; both figures grew at a 6% clip in Q2.
    • Verizon's wireless service revenue rose 8.4% Y/Y in Q3, even with Q2 and outpacing sub growth. Wireless op. margin was 33.8%, +140 bps Q/Q and +200 bps Y/Y. 67% of retail postpaid subs now use smarphones (up from 64% in Q2), and 42% use a shared data plan.
    • Retail postpaid ARPA +2% Q/Q and +7% Y/Y to $155.74. But retail postpaid churn was 0.97%, up from 0.91% a year ago.
    • FiOS Internet and TV net adds totaled 173K and 135K, respectively. That compares with 161K and 140K in Q2. FiOS Internet and TV subs totd 5.9M and 5.2M at quarter's end. Total broadband connections rose by 56K Q/Q to 9M. Consumer wireline ARPU rose 8.7% Y/Y to $112.86.
    • However, wireline revenue fell 1% Y/Y, as declines in small business, "Core" enterprise, and global wholesale services offset gains for consumer retail and "strategic" enterprise. 371K wireline voice connections were lost, total voice connections -6% Y/Y to 21.5M. Wireline op. margin was 1.6%, up from 0.8% in Q2 and 0.4% a year ago.
    • Q3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 9:38 AM
  • CYS

    CYS management pleased with Yellen appointment

    • The cheapest fixed income assets anywhere across the globe are residential mortgage-backed securities, says CYS Investments (CYS +1.5%) CEO Kevin Grant on the company earnings call. Grant was responding to a question about maybe increasing the size of stock buybacks. The questioner responded that that statement could mean buying the stock of companies which own MBS (boosted buybacks). Grant's retort was to read into it what you like.
    • Responding to another question, Grant says spending all possible funds on buybacks would be the textbook corporate finance move given the big discount to book value CYS' shares are trading at. Being a REIT however, and having investors dependent on a stream of dividends, makes that impossible.
    • September 30 reported book value of $10.10 puts last night's closing price of $8.27 at an 18.1% discount.
    • Bullish about company prospects going forward, Grant says he would feel a whole lot differently had it been Larry Summers instead of Janet Yellen picked to lead the Fed.
    • Q3 results from last night.
    • Related ETFs: MORT, MORL, REM.

    Peabody tops estimates, guides higher, shares +4.8% premarket

    • Peabody Energy (NYSE:BTU) +4.8% premarket after beating Q3 earnings expectations and guiding FY 2013 above consensus.
    • However, BTU posted an unadjusted loss of $0.10/share vs. a year-ago gain of $0.16, and income from continuing operations fell to $0.06/share from last year's $0.46; results were affected by lower gross margins and higher depreciation, depletion and amortization expenses that were partially offset by lower income taxes vs. last year.

    Big trading revenue drop hits Goldman

    • A big miss on revenue has Goldman (NYSE:GS)Â off 3%Â in early trades after the release of Q3 earnings, even as the bank tries to soften things with a 10% dividend boost. Blankfein: "The Q3 results reflected a period of slow client activity ... Still, we saw various signs that our clients are prepared to act on significant transactions and we believe that the firm is well positioned to help our clients accomplish their objectives."
    • Investment banking revenue of $1.17B is roughly unchanged from a year ago, with advisory (M&A) business way down and underwriting (IPO) business way up. The backlog "increased significantly" from Q2.

"FICC operated in a challenging environment, which was characterized by economic uncertainty, difficult market-making conditions in certain businesses and lower levels of activity." Indeed.
    • Ouch!Â Compensation expense of $2.38B fell 35% from a year ago. The ratio of compensation and benefits to total revenue is 41% over the year's first nine months vs. 44% a year ago.
